Situation1: They join in when the family talks about possible weekend plans.
Expectation2: Write clean, maintainable, and efficient code
Situation2: The new feature is nearly ready but performance warnings appear in code reviews
Story: I sat at the dinner table, half-listening as my stepbrother excitedly listed ideas for our weekend together—hiking, a movie marathon, maybe even a day trip to the lake. My stepmom’s eyes sparkled with hope that I’d join in, and I could feel the unspoken expectation: be present, be part of the family. But my phone buzzed with another Slack notification from work. The new feature I’d been building was almost done, but the code review was full of red flags—performance issues, suggestions for cleaner logic. My team lead’s comments echoed in my mind: “We need this to be solid before Monday.” I wanted to reassure my family, to say yes to their plans, but my mind kept drifting back to the code, the looming deadline, the pressure to deliver something I could be proud of. I felt torn, the warmth of family togetherness on one side, the cold logic of my IDE on the other, both demanding more than I could give.
